subject: Leadership
title: Whistleblowing and Speak-Up Culture
description: A micro-lesson that makes Whistleblowing and Speak-Up Culture usable.

hook.text: Enron employees saw the fraud. Most stayed silent. The few who spoke up were ignored, then punished.

buildup.text: Miceli and Near's research: whistleblowers face retaliation in over half of cases. Speaking up is personally costly.

discovery.text: Organizations with strong speak-up cultures detect fraud 50% earlier than those that rely on audits and controls alone.

twist.text: Anonymous hotlines help but aren't enough. If leaders punish messengers, no hotline will save the organization.

climax.text: Protect whistleblowers legally and culturally. Thank them publicly. Make speaking up a valued act, not a career risk.

punchline.text: The canary in the coal mine only helps if you listen before it dies.

quiz.question: Why are anonymous hotlines alone insufficient for ethics?
options: If leaders punish messengers, no system overcomes the fear
